availability.licence: This description is released under a CC0 licence.

msDesc.head: Chronicle, English, 1447 × 1490s; Trilingual poetic anthology, Herefordshire, 1272 × 1290s

binding.p: Mottled calf binding executed for Thomas Wilkins, finished 9 January 1693, according to his memorandum (Hill, p. 276, who argues that the two parts were already in a single volume at this time). A pattern of three-line fillets in two rectangles, one placed inside the other, mitred at each corner, back and front. Bruce Barker-Benfield notes that two parchment stubs precede the upper and lower paper flyleaves: one has a gilt stamp from 17th-century binder’s waste, probably from a small notebook; the other is from the same book, folded over the spine. Remnants of clasps.
Rebacked in the early 20th century, with the remnants of the Wilkins spine affixed to the inside of the lower board.

history.provenance: Thomas Wilkins (1625/26–1699), rector of St Mary’s church, Llanvair Discoed, Monmouthshire, who attended Jesus College in 1641. Inscribed prior to the book being trimmed, fols. 1r (twice), 56r, 143v, 143b verso, 155r, 192r, 257r.
history.acquisition:
Given to Jesus College; inscribed, Bibliothecae Coll. Jesu
Oxon. hoc Manuscriptum
(cum duobus alijs)
humillimè D.D.D.
Tho. Wilkins L.L.B. Rector
B.M. super Montem in Agro
Glamorganensi (fol. ii recto), with similar notes in MSS. 27 and 119. Wilkins gave these three books on 9 January 1693, according to his note in a copy of John Prise’s Historia Brytannicae defensio (1573) in the National Library of Wales, W.s. 1573(a), signed Tho. Wilkins on the upper flyleaf, with the following note on the lower flyleaf: Memorandum that on Munday the 9th of January 1693 I gave three velom MSpts to Jesus College Library, & sente them up with Rees Bowen: All three new bound & claspt viz 1 One large thicke 4to, a viry necessary Canon law-book Latine 2 One other 4to being 17 of Brittish Storyes, & written for Griffydd ab Ifan, ab Trehaiarn of Cantref maior, now in Carmarthenshire Anno Domini 1346 3 An Antient Cronicle ab Anno 900 usque ad Annum 1444. Latine, & a Saxon-Manuscript bound with it, Being the Poetry of Mr Johan of Guldeuorde now called, Gifford.

source.p: Description by Andrew Dunning (November 2022), with thanks to Timothy Cutts of the National Library of Wales. Previously described:

listBibl.bibl: H. O. Coxe, Catalogus codicum mss. qui in collegiis aulisque Oxoniensibus hodie adservantur (1852)

msItem.author: Ranulf Higden
msItem.title: Polychronicon
msItem.note: Begins with book 6, chapter 4; concludes with an unidentified continuation.
A note by a college librarian labels the work Chronicon Regum Angliæ ab anno 900 ad 1445 (fol. ii verso).
msItem.incipit: Edwardus cognomento senior regnauit post patrem xxvij. annis literarum cultu
msItem.explicit: Tunc dux Ricardus Eboracensis. erat regens francie.
msItem.note: The continuation was written around 1447 according to Charles Lethbridge Kingsford, ‘A Legend of Sigismund’s Visit to England’, The English Historical Review 26, no. 104 (October 1911): 750–51.
Followed by added verses on Westminster in the hand of Thomas Ragland.

supportDesc.support: paper and parchment (used for the outer and innermost bifolia of quires)
supportDesc.foliation: Fols. 1–143, 143b also have a medieval foliation, ‘·lxix·’ through ‘·ccxvi·’, indicating the loss of sixty-eight leaves.
supportDesc.collation: 116 (fols. 1–16), 2–520 (fols. 17–96), 620–6 (fols. 97–110; 12th partially torn away and 13th–18th mostly excised), 78 (fols. 111–118), 812 (fols. 119–130), 914 (fols. 131–143, 143b). Blank parchment stubs sewn into the centres of quires 7–9 to strengthen these in lieu of full parchment bifolia.

layoutDesc.layout: Ruled in pencil, 27–35 long lines, ruled space 155 100

decoDesc.decoNote: Three-line initials in red for new monarchs.
Rubrics break the work into sections by monarch and provide marginal headings.

history.provenance:
Sir Thomas Ragland (fl. 1563); inscribed, thys ys thomas raglandys boke
he that steleth hym salbe hangyd by a crowke
and thomas (fol. 107r; DIMEV 1896); added verse (fol. 143b recto); God saue the kyng
and the quyne also
thomas (fol. 143b verso). His stepfather, Sir Edward Carne (died 1561), was a commissioner at the Dissolution and may have acquired the book from a religious house.

James Carne, a cousin of Thomas Ragland: inscribed in a 16th- or 17th-century hand, thys ys Ihames carne ys hand record of mayster thomas carne and (fol. 47r). Thomas Carne was the half-brother of Thomas Ragland.

Practice legal entries from the 17th century suggest continued ownership in Glamorganshire: Noverint universi per presentes me Morganum Llewis de Llantrissent in Comitat. Glamorgan Arg. teneri et firmiter obligari (fol. 46v); Whereas complaint hath been mad vnto me one of his Majesties Justices of in and for the County of Glamorgan (fol. 47r).

msItem.title: The passion of our Lord
msItem.rubric: Ici cumence la passyun ihesu crist en engleys.
Incipit prologus.
msItem.incipit:
Ihereþ ny one lutele tale. þat ich eu wille telle.
As we vyndeþ hit i write in þe godspelle.
msItem.explicit:
And heo vre erende bere sois hire ywune
Mid alle oþer halewe to hire swete sune Amen
msItem.note: Transcript of the first 84 lines by Edward Lluyd in MS. Ashmole 1449, pp. 163–66.

msItem.title: Added verse attributed to Master John of Guildford
msItem.note: Copied in the 17th century by Thomas Wilkins in a facsimile script. In parte of a broaken leafe of this MS. I found these verses written wherby the Author may bee gues’t at.
msItem.quote:
Mayster Iohan eu greteþ of Guldeuorde þo.
And sendeþ eu to Seggen. þat synge nul he no.
He on þisse wise he wille enoy his song"
God Louerd of Heuene. beo vs alle among.

msItem.note: Blank (last page of the first quire).

msItem.title: The owl and the nightingale
msItem.rubric: Incipit altercacio inter filomenam et Bubonem.
msItem.incipit:
Ich wes in one sumere dale
In oneswiþe dyele hale
msItem.explicit:
He can iceu namore telle
her nys namore of þisse spelle

msItem.title: Poema morale
msItem.rubric: Tractatus quidam in anglico.
msItem.incipit:
Ich am eldre þan ich wes a winter and ek on lore
Ich welde more þan ich dude my wyt auhte beo more
msItem.explicit:
Bidde nu we leoue freond yonge and ek olde
Þat he þat þis wryt wrot his saule beo þer ac holde

msItem.title: The saws of Saint Bede
msItem.incipit:
Þees holy gostes myhte
Vs helpe and rede and dihte
msItem.explicit:
Among þan englen bryhte
Wunyen and beo mote

msItem.title: The Samaritan woman
msItem.rubric: Incipit de muliere Samaritana
msItem.incipit:
Þo ihesu crist an eorþe was mylde weren his dede
Alle heo beoþ on boke iwryten þat me may heom rede
msItem.explicit:
And þus was þes bureuh a red vt of helle sore
And by leuede on al myhty god nuwe & euer more

msItem.title: On fortune
msItem.incipit: Weole þu art a waried þing vneuene constu dele
msItem.explicit: Þe poure i londe naueth no lot with riche for to mele

msItem.title: Admonition to prepare for death
msItem.incipit:
Mon may longe lyues wene
Ac ofte him lyeþ þe wrench
msItem.explicit:
Wurcheþ him þyne euer mo
Mon ne do þu nouht swo

msItem.title: An orison to the Virgin Mary
msItem.incipit:
On hire is al my lif i long
of hwam ich wille synge
msItem.explicit:
Nu and euer mo
To longe Ich habbe soth ibeo

msItem.title: Fragmentary poem on the Annunciation
msItem.incipit:
of þine swete wordes ich am swiþe gled
Ich am godes wenche ful wel ich habbe i sped
msItem.explicit:
þat for his swete moder luue þat feyr is and hende
Bringe vs to þe blisse þat lesteþ buten ende
msItem.note: Eleven lines on fol. 188v and seven lines on fol. 181r.

msItem.title: The five joys of our Lady Saint Mary
msItem.rubric: Her bigynneþ þe vif Blyssen of vre leuedi Seynte Marie.
msItem.incipit:
Leuedy for þare blisse
þat þu heddest at þe triune
Þo þu wistest myd i wisse
þat ihesu wolde beo þi sune
msItem.explicit:
O vre sunnes make vs clene
& yef vs þat eche lyht
And to heouene vs alle i mene
louerd þu bryng for wel þu miht

msItem.title: Against simony
msItem.rubric: Hwon holy chireche is vnder uote
msItem.incipit:
Hwile wes seynte peter i cleped symon
þo queþ vre louerd him to þu schalt hoten ston
msItem.explicit:
For his swete moder luue þat is so veyr and swote
Þat we in þisse lyue hit i seon mote

msItem.title: Doomsday
msItem.rubric: Incipit de die iudicii.
msItem.incipit:
Hwenne ich þenche of domesday ful sore ich may adrede
Þer schal after his werk uych mon fongen mede
msItem.explicit:
For his holy nome and for hire erendynge
Þat he ure saule to heueryche brynge

msItem.title: On death
msItem.incipit:
I hereþ of one þinge þat ye owen of þenche
Ye þat weryeþ þat riche schrud and sytteþ on eurebence
msItem.explicit:
And lete vs hatye þat wouh and luuþe þat ryhte
And bringe vre saule to heoueriche lyhte

msItem.title: Ten abuses of the age
msItem.incipit:
Hwan þu sixst vnleode
king þat is wilful
And Domes mon ny mynde
preost þat is wilde
msItem.explicit:
Lond wiþ vten lawe
Al so seyde Bede
Wo þere þeode

msItem.title: A little sooth sermon against forbidden fruits
msItem.incipit:
Herkneþ alle gode men and stylle sitteþ a dun
And ich ou wile tellen a lutel soþ sermun
msItem.explicit:
Al so wis so he god is for hire erendynge
To þe blysse of heouene he vs alle brynge

msItem.title: Antiphona de sancto Thoma Martyre
msItem.rubric: Incipit antiphona de sancto Thoma martyre in anglico.
msItem.incipit:
Haly thomas of heoueriche
Alle apostles eueliche
msItem.explicit:
þu ert froure a mong mon kunne
help vs nv of vre sunne Amen

msItem.title: Exhortation to serve Christ
msItem.incipit:
Hwi ne serue we crist and secheþ his sauht
seoþþe vs wel at þe font fulluht by tauht
msItem.explicit:
Þureh þe riche blode þe roche to chon
Louerd haue mercy of vs euervychon

msItem.author: Thomas of Hales
msItem.title: Love rune
msItem.rubric: Incipit quidam cantus quem composuit frater Thomas de Hales de ordine fratrum Minorum. ad instanciam cuiusdam puelle deo dicate.
msItem.incipit:
A Mayde cristes me bit yorne
Þat ich hire wurche a luue ron
msItem.explicit:
And yeue him god endynge
Þat haueþ i wryten þis ilke wryt

msItem.title: Fragmentary poem on the Annunciation
msItem.rubric: Item cantus.
msItem.incipit:
From heouene in to eorþe god gretynge he sende
Bi on Archaungle þat to Marye wende
msItem.explicit:
Mones imone on me ne may nomon fynde
of dred wes þat mayde
msItem.note: Eleven lines on fol. 188v and seven lines on fol. 181r.

msItem.title: Fragmentary poem on forgiveness
msItem.incipit:
Naueþ my saule bute fur and ys
& þe lichome eorþe and treo
msItem.explicit:
Hwenne deþ heom lat to þe murehþe
þat neuer ne byþ undon

msItem.title: Signs of death
msItem.incipit:
Wenne þin heou blokeþ
and þi strengþe wokeþ
msItem.explicit:
þeonne biþ hit sone of þe
al so þu neuer ner

msItem.title: Three sorrowful tidings
msItem.incipit:
Yche day me cumeþ tydinges þreo
for wel swiþe sore beoþ heo
msItem.explicit:
Þe þridde is my meste kare
Þat ich not hwider ich scal fare
msItem.note: Transcript of this and the following three items by Edward Lluyd in Aberystwyth, National Library of Wales, MS. Peniarth 120, pp. 601–17.

msItem.title: Sayings of Alfred
msItem.rubric: Incipiunt documenta regis Alurede.
msItem.incipit:
At Seuorde sete þeynes monye fele Biscopes and feole bok ilered
Eorles prute knyhtes egleche þar wes þe eorl Alurich
msItem.explicit:
Þe mon þe spareþ yeorde and yonge child and let hit arixlye
Þat he hit areche ne may þat him schal on ealde sore reowe

msItem.title: In praise of Christ
msItem.rubric: Tractatus quidam.
msItem.incipit:
Louerd crist ich þe grete
þu art so mylde and swete
from heouene louerd þu hider come
msItem.explicit:
Þat my saule habbe lyffe
Þat myn ende come to eche blysse Amen

msItem.title: Homily on true love
msItem.rubric: Tractatus quidam.
msItem.incipit:
Þeo soþe luue a mong vs beo
Wyþ vten euch endynge
msItem.explicit:
And lede vs in to heouene blys
& sette vs on hus ryht honde

msItem.title: The shires and hundreds of England
msItem.rubric: Her bigynneþ þe Syren. and þe hundredes of engelonde.
msItem.incipit: Angle lond is eyhte hundred myle long from penwyþ steorte.
msItem.explicit: Þis is unde al⹎ xxvi· þusend hida. and on half hundred.

msItem.title: Assize of bread of England
msItem.rubric: Assisa panis Anglie
msItem.incipit: Quando frumentum venditur pro ·xij· denar’. tunc Walstellus
msItem.explicit: Quando pro ·vij· s. tunc ponderabit ·xix· solid’ ·vi· denar’.

msItem.author: Guillaume le Clerc de Normandie
msItem.title: Vie de Tobie
msItem.rubric: Ici comence de Tobye.
msItem.incipit:
Cil ke seme bone semence.
V bone parole comence.
Deyt garder ceo est uerite fine. Ke sur pere. ne sur espyne.
msItem.explicit:
Por ki il enseuelyseit.
Les cors quant leysir aueyt.
Si cum vus orrez en la estorie.
Ke ben est digne de memorie.

msItem.title: The eleven pains of hell
msItem.rubric: Ici comencent les vnze peynes de enfern. les queus synt pool vist.
msItem.incipit:
Plest uus oyer une demaunde.
Ke li deable fist estraunge.
msItem.explicit:
And he is curteys and hendy.
Þi. god him lete wel endy.
Amen.
msItem.finalRubric: Expliciunt ·xi· pene Inferni. quas vidit Beatus Paulus.

msItem.title: Le doctrinal Sauvage
msItem.rubric: Ici cumence le Doctrinal.
msItem.incipit:
Sceo fust. vn ryches heom ki me vousist entendre.
Cheualer. clerk. et lay. ben i pust aprendre.
msItem.explicit:
Les bons entendemens. ben entendre e oyr
Peot eom tele chose aprendre. dunt il peot ioyr. Amen.

msItem.author: Chardri
msItem.title: La vie des set dormanz
msItem.rubric: Ici comence la Vie de Set Dormaunz.
msItem.incipit:
La uertu deu. ke tuz iurs dure.
E tuz iurs est certeyne e pure.
msItem.explicit:
Amen. Amen. dites en haut⹎
E ieo le conferm. si deu me saut.
Amen.

msItem.author: Chardri
msItem.title: La vie de seint Josaphaz
msItem.rubric: Ici comence la vie Seynt Iosaphaz.
msItem.incipit:
Ki uout a nul ben entendre.
Par ensample peot aprendre.
msItem.explicit:
Maunde chardri saluz sanz fin.
E au uespre. e au matyn. Amen.

msItem.author: Chardri
msItem.title: Le petit plet
msItem.rubric: Ici cumence le petyt ple. entre le Iuuencel e le Veylard.
msItem.incipit:
Beaus duz seynurs pur vus dedure.
Vus cutrey un enueysure.
msItem.explicit:
Amen amen chescun en die.
Ore nus eyt tuz. le fiz marie. Amen.

supportDesc.foliation: In addition to the modern foliation of fols. 144–257, an earlier modern foliation continues the medieval foliation, beginning with ‘217’ at fol. 144; indistinct after ‘262’.
supportDesc.collation: 1–312 (fols. 144–179), 412–2 (fols. 180–189; second bifolium missing, leaving gaps after fols. 180 and 188), 5–712 (fols. 190–225), 812–2 (fols. 226–235; fourth bifolium missing, leaving gaps after fols. 228 and 232), 912 (fols. 236–247), 1012–2 (fols. 248–257; outermost bifolium missing, with a gap after fol. 247).

layoutDesc.layout: Mostly ruled in pencil, in 30–32 long lines, ruled space 143 118
Fols. 156r–168v, 175r–178v, 195v–257v are in pencil, in two columns of 32–39 lines, ruled space 143 118

handDesc.handNote: Gothic textualis, copied in a single hand, written above top line.
Some verses were left incomplete by the scribe, finished in what Ker calls an unusual current and backward-sloping hand written in brown ink soon after 1300. Ker, pp. xviii–xix provides a list.

decoDesc.decoNote: Lombardic capitals at the opening of new works with penwork decoration.
Coloured initials indicating new sections, alternating between blue and red.
Rubrics for work headings and speakers in dialogues.

origin.p: The Linguistic Atlas of Early Middle English analyses the scribe’s dialect as belonging to east Herefordshire. Based on Ker’s dating of the manuscript to the second half of the 13th century, Cartlidge, ‘The Date of The Owl and the Nightingale’, argues that the poem was written after the death of King Henry III in 1272. Hill (p. 273) hypothesizes that the manuscript’s contents are connected to the household of Richard Swinfield, bishop of Hereford 1283–1317. The manuscript is derived from an exemplar common with London, British Library, Cotton MS. Caligula A. ix and Vatican City, Biblioteca Apostolica, MS. Reg. lat. 1659. The only other record of a copy of The Owl and the Nightingale is in the 1400 catalogue of Titchfield Abbey (CBMLC, P6), which also held copies of Chardri’s works.

listBibl.bibl: David N. Bell, The Libraries of the Cistercians, Gilbertines, and Premonstratensians, Corpus of British Medieval Library Catalogues 3 (London, 1992).
Betty Hill, ‘Oxford, Jesus College MS 29, Part II: Contents, Technical Matters, Compilation, and Its History to c. 1695’, Notes and Queries 50, no. 3 (September 2003): 268–76.
Neil Cartlidge, ‘The Date of The Owl and the Nightingale’, Medium Ævum 65, no. 2 (1996): 230–247.
Neil Cartlidge, The Works of Chardri. Three Poems in the French of Thirteenth-Century England: The Life of the Seven Sleepers, The Life of St. Josaphaz and The Little Debate (Tempe, AZ, 2015).
Susanna Fein, The Owl and the Nightingale and the English Poems of Oxford, Jesus College, MS 29 (II), Middle English Text Series (Kalamazoo, MI, 2022).

N.R. Ker, The Owl and the Nightingale: Reproduced in Facsimile from the Surviving Manuscripts, Jesus College Oxford 29 and British Museum Cotton Caligula A.ix, Early English Text Society 251 (Oxford, 1963).
Jane Roberts, Guide to Scripts Used in English Writings up to 1500 (Liverpool, 2015), no. 32 (pp. 146–48).

revisionDesc.change: Andrew Dunning revised with consultation of original.
